p:
Although precipitating atmospheric vortices known as low-pressure systems (LPS) are found in all monsoon regions, their presence is most prominent over India, where an average of 13 (± 2.5) storms develop each boreal summer, with most originating over the Bay of Bengal (BoB) and adjoining land ( 1
– 5). The intensification and propagation of these storms are linked to the strength of the larger-scale monsoon circulation and interactions with precipitating convection ( 6, 7). The mean monsoon circulation is argued to have weakened in recent decades, with a variety of reasons advanced for this slowdown of winds ( 8, 9). Some studies have also reported a reduction in LPS activity since the mid-20th century ( 10 – 12), but the reliability of this trend has been questioned due to inconsistencies among observational datasets ( 13).
